Award.AwardTitle: OP: Spatial and spectral control of quantum dot single photon emitters for scalable photonic devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project title: Engineering materials for the scalable production of new electronic devices that use controlled emission and absorption of single photons

Abstract

Non-Technical: Modern photonic and electronic devices operate via the generation and transmission of many thousands of photons or electrons, respectively. Although scientists have known for many years that devices that operate with single photons or single electrons could enable revolutionary new functionality, it is extremely difficult to engineer reliable devices that operate at this level. For example, previous efforts to build a material that contains many independent but identical single photon emitters have failed because the emitters are formed at random locations and are not identical. The supported researchers will engineer a new material that overcomes this limit. First, the emitters will be forced to grow at specified locations by pre-patterning the surface on which the emitters grow. Second, each site will contain a pair of emitters whose interaction can be controlled to tune the emission to the value desired for device operation. This work will include sustained engagement with the students, parents, and teachers of an elementary school with an extremely high percentage of economically-disadvantaged students.

Technical: Optoelectronic devices that operate at the quantum limit of single photons, charges, and spins have long been viewed as a promising platform for quantum device technologies. These quantum technologies promise many advances, including fundamentally secure modes of information transmission and exquisite sensors with very low detection thresholds. The ideal device would leverage wafer-scale semiconductor processing methods to create on-chip photonic devices that emit, route, manipulate, and absorb single photons. The fundamental component of such a device would have to be a single optically-active nanostructure with quantized energy states. However, efforts to create chip-scalable platforms for single-photon technologies have been hampered by the challenge of creating optically-active nanostructures with both spatial control of their position and spectral control over their emission energy.

The approach to be taken in this project overcomes these challenges by leveraging two recent advances in molecular beam epitaxial growth. First, pre-patterned substrates will be used to spatially control the nucleation of "template" quantum dots (QDs) whose optical quality is unimportant. A series of these "template" QDs will be used to transfer the spatial pattern to a growth surface well-separated from the pre-patterned surface in order to obtain high optical quality from the QDs that are used for photon emission and absorption. Second, the optically-active structure will be a complex of two QDs stacked along the growth axis such that applied electric fields can be used to tune the optical absorption and emission wavelengths. Prior work on these coupled QD pairs by the PI shows that they can tune optical emission wavelengths over a range at least one order of magnitude larger than that available from single QDs. The team will embed the QD pairs within a p-i-n diode structure that enables the local application of electric fields to individual QD pairs. The individual wavelength tunability of each QD pair provides the mechanism for deterministic spectral overlap with target photonic device wavelengths.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of Quantum Information Science (QIS) is to create devices that leverage the unique properties of quantum mechanics to create new technologies with applications in quantum computing, sensing, and secure communications. Qubits are the basis for these technologies, and we use qubits defined by the spin projection of single electrons or holes confined in InAs quantum dots (QDs) and quantum dot molecules. There has been tremendous progress in demonstrating quantum control and quantum gates in this type of qubit and they remain very promising because of their strong optical activity and the opportunity to use photons for ultrafast all-optical implementation of quantum control protocols. Despite this promise, InAs QDs have fallen behind many other material platforms as a material platform for QIS for two reasons: 1) Traditional Stranski-Krastanov growth methods results in randomly-nucleated InAs QDs that cannot be deterministically integrated into photonic devices. Previous attempts to create site-templated quantum dots have resulted in QDs with poor optical quality. 2) Each InAs QD in an ensemble has slightly different energy, which means that they would each require different optical frequencies for control or coupling. The work supported by this award focused on addressing these two problems in order to advance InAs quantum dots as a viable and scalable material platform for QIS. Specifically, we aimed to develop fabrication and growth protocols that achieve spatial and spectral control over individual QDs while maintaining optical quality and enabling the subsequent fabrication of photonic elements registered to the QD locations.

We have developed fabrication and growth protocols that allow for the MBE growth of InAs QDs at pre-determined locations defined by an array of etch pits with template sites separated by as much as 10 um and with site-occupancy of 89%. The large spacing between QDs (up to 10 um) is important because it allows for the fabrication of electrical contacts that can individually tune single QDs or QD pairs at each array site. Because similar site-templating processes have been shown to produce quantum dots with poor optical quality, we also worked on development of strain-induced alignment of stacked quantum dots that we anticipate will allow the growth of high-optical-quality, site-templated quantum dots above the patterned substrate. Importantly, all of these fabrication and growth protocols include the creation of alignment markers that survive the MBE growth process, meaning that subsequent fabrication of photonic structures such as cavities or waveguides can be registered to the QD locations. We also developed an ultra-thin diode that is compatible with the site-templating strategy defined above and will enable spectral control over the QD emission. These ultra-thin n-i-p membranes allow spectral control through the application of electrical fields to individual QDs or QD pairs without the deposition of metal electrodes that would degrade cavity Q factors. We note that the catastrophic failure of our existing OSEMI Nextgen MBE necessitated frequent maintenance and re-calibration, causing significant research delays. With the support of the NSF MRI program, we recently acquired a new Veeco GenXplor MBE that will resolve these problems going forward. In the last year of this program we transferred the growth and optimization of InAs quantum dots, as well as the gallium-assisted deoxidation procedure, to the new MBE machine. Finally, we developed processes for fabricating photonic structures such as photonic crystal cavities, waveguides, traditional waveguides, and outcouplers in these ultra-thin n-i-p membranes. This included development of a chlorine-based ICP etch process for flexible fabrication of various photonic structures as well as the development of a algorithmic image analysis software for improving process optimization of periodic structures such as the targeted photonic crystals.

With support from this award, three graduate students were trained to conduct and report scientific research. In parallel, we developed an extensive partnership with Tarbiyah Islamic School of Delaware, providing both equipment and training to support their science education programs. Similarly, we provided equipment and training for the undergraduate members of the Deep Roots Outreach Program, supporting their efforts to provide sustained mentoring to K12 students at schools with significant under-represented and under-resourced students populations. Our program of training for teachers, local community organizations, and registered student organizations has significantly increased the number of times in which our Lending Library of science education modules has been requested and implemented without in-person assistance from our staff. We continue to run a significant number of staff-supported events as well.
